Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2011 10:14AM invisible wrote: I could have been your cousin a year ago.  My mantra was why would I choose to make myself physically sick?  I may have cancer but I feel great right now. Unlike her, I did not refuse surgery, but it was touch and go up to my first infusion.  I was both terribly afraid of the side effects I'd both witnessed in my relatives and read about.  I addition, I believe substantially depressed.  Talk therapy for the depression and fear are completely compatible with a holistic lifestyle.  I'd encourage her to start seeing a therapist who works with cancer patients and see what develops.

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2013 07:24AM - edited Aug 25, 2013 08:44AM by invisible Mike - I'm recently diagnosed myself.  Given the high number of unknowns and my relative good health at this point I've told my 13 and 18 year old only that I'm back in active treatment.  The older child moved into the freshman dorms at university on Friday, and we live thousands of miles away.  I didn't want to burden him with this information when he'd be separated from me for so long.  I think there will be plenty of opportunity in the course of events to disclose additional information as it becomes relevant.  Certainly they're old enough to handle more information and if they ask me before the opportunity presents itself, I'll tell all.

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2013 12:41AM invisible wrote: y mother, in her later years began sending my sister and I vingettes of her own youth and times with her mother who died when she was 12.  How her mother insisted they do the dishes by rinsing them with boilng water to sterilize them,  The sense of achiement she had when her mother deemed her competent at age six to iron father's shirts,  How preparing lunch for a church function made her moritfied but left her with the few recipies she has from her own mother, not her step mother.  I am kicking myself now for not saving these messages.  They provided a wonderful context of the family she come from, how it shaped her and I can see parallels in myself.    On the subject of recipies - they can be wonderful shared moments of history and enhancers of memory.  My sister and I are still trying to recreate with various degrees of success one of my Dad's frequent contributions to the dinner table.  It's always a hoot to taste the latest version and share memories.  I'd encourage you to cook some of your recipies with your daughter now, and include the actual recipies, properly measured or not, in your box.  Kudos to you for being proactive about this.
